question: Compute the peak wavelength in micrometers of blackbody radiation emitted by the cold reservoir when a heat engine performs 210.59 J of work per cycle while exhausting 513.55 J of heat under $Q_h = W + Q_c$, with a Carnot engine operating between this cold reservoir and a hot reservoir at 596.8°C exhibiting identical efficiency, using $\sigma = 5.670374419 \times 10^{-8}  \text{W/m}^2\text{K}^4$ and Wien's displacement constant $b = 2898  \mu\text{m}\cdot\text{K}$, where the radiation power per square meter corresponds to the quantity established by the efficiency equivalence condition.
subject: physics
constant_ev: Assume Q_h = W + Q_c when calculating the heat absorbed from the hot reservoir
Use σ = 5.670374419 × 10⁻⁸ W/m²K⁴ in the blackbody radiation power calculation
Use b = 2898 μm·K in Wien's displacement law calculation
derived_ev: The cold reservoir temperature for the Carnot engine is 344.5 degrees Celsius
The cold reservoir temperature in Kelvin is 617.65 K
The radiation power emitted by the cold reservoir as a blackbody radiator is 8252.42 W/m²
The peak wavelength of blackbody radiation emitted by the cold reservoir is 4.691 μm

tier1_result.reasoning: The solver's 4.70 μm agrees with the expected 4.691 μm within reasonable rounding tolerance (difference 0.009 μm), and the calculation used the correct physics (Carnot efficiency and Wien's displacement law).
